titleStmt.title: Places
titleStmt.funder: American Philosophical Society, Beinecke Library, Bibliographical Society of America, Blossman Foundation, Huntington Library, Louisiana Board of Regents, National Endowment for the Humanities, NINES, Pierpont Morgan Library, South Central Modern Language Association, and Southeastern Louisiana University

distributor.name: Southeastern Louisiana University Department of English

sourceDesc.p: Born digitally, prepared by David C. Hanson.

terrain.desc: Length: 6.50 sq mi

event.label: Passed through in route to Dover.

note.p: Mary states they walked up Blackheath and Shooter's Hill to get to Dartford.

terrain.desc: An area located in the Greenwich bourough of east London.

event.label: Passed through in route to Dover.

note.p: Walked up Shooter's Hill before arriving at Dartford.

terrain.desc: Length: 28.10 sq mi

event.label: Pass through in route to Dover.

note.p: Changed at Dartford before reaching Rochester while in route to Dover.

terrain.desc: Mary says that it is one long hill.

event.label: Pass through in route to Dover.
Pass through in route to Dover

note.p: Dined in Canterbury after leaving Rochester.

event.label: Pass through in route to Dover

note.p: Changed in Canterbury before reaching Dover.

event.label: Depart by steamboat at 9 for Calais.

note.p: Had tea after arrival, and breakfast at 8 before departure.

terrain.desc: Calais “is a fortress of the 2nd class, situated in the most barren and unpicturesque district, with sandhills raised by the wind and the sea on the one side, and morasses on the other, contributing considerably to its military strength, but by no means to the beauty of its position” (Murray Hand‐book [1836], 85).

event.label: Arrived by English packet after two and a half hours at sea (English Channel).
Departed for Lille at 7 in the morning.

note.p: Mary says they were escorted to the Custom House, where their boxes and Anne were searched, by an officer. They stayed at L'hotel de Bourbon or Rossignol, toured the cathedral, and walked the town.

p.ref: Account of a Tour on the Continent (MS IA g2)

terrain.desc: Length: 2.76 sq mi
“Andres, a small town on the canal named after it” (Murray Hand‐book [1836], 86)..

note.p: Stage 1 of this leg of the tour.

terrain.desc: Length: 6.3 sq mi
“A fortified town in a marshy situation” (Murray Hand‐book [1836], 86)..
A rather large town.

event.label: Pass through in route to Lille

terrain.desc: Length: 4.88 sq mi

“Cassel is most agreeably situated on a hill commanding a view much celebrated in France, but which, after all, will bear no comparison with that from the Malvern Hills in England. It extends over the flat and fertile plains of Flanders, and as far as the white cliffs of England into 3 different kingdoms; includes 32 towns and 100 villages” (Murray Hand‐book [1836], 87)..
A town situated on a hill.

p.ref: “The way was long, and yet ʼtwas sweet” [poem]
“When shall we get up this hill” [“Cassel,” prose]
“When shall we get up this hill” [“Cassel,” prose]
“Cassel and Saint Omer Corpus Christi Procession” [drawing]

note.p: Meant only to dine, but was so pleased with the town that they decided to stay the night at Hotel d'Angelterre. They witnessed a procession of images of the Virgin Mary and Savior, followed by townsmen. The procession came from a church and went all round town. As the procession passed, the people in the town knelt and prayed.

terrain.desc: Length: 16.76 sq mi

event.label: Pass through in route to Lille.

terrain.desc: Length: 2.42 sq mi
“The road here almost touches upon the Belgic frontier” (Murray Hand‐book [1836], 87).

event.label: Pass through in route to Lille

terrain.desc: Length: 13.4 sq mi
Lille is “handsomely built, and surrounded by fortifications which render it one of the strongest places in France” (Murray Hand‐book [1836], 87).

note.p: Stage 3. Mary notes that they looked at a cathedral and visited a citadel. John Ruskin also drew.

terrain.desc: “Pont‐a‐Tressin. – The last post town in France” (Murray Hand‐book [1836], 88).

note.p: Stage 1 of this leg of the tour.

terrain.desc: Length: 82.53 sq mi
Before entering Tournai, French Custom House located at French/Belgian border.

note.p: Stage 2. Were stopped and searched at both French and Belgian Custom House.

terrain.desc: Length: 28.39 sq mi

event.label: Pass through in route to Brussles

note.p: Stage 1 of this leg of tour to Brussels.

terrain.desc: Length: 49.02 sq mi
Ath “is a fortress on the Dender” (Murray Hand‐book [1836], 89).

event.label: Pass through in route to Brussels.

terrain.desc: Length: 15.67 sq mi

event.label: Pass through in route to Brussels

terrain.desc: Length: 17.14 sq mi
Located southwest of Brussels.

event.label: Pass through in route to Brussels

note.p: Mary writes it as Hal. Stage 4.

terrain.desc: Length: 12.59 sq mi

“Brussels, the capital of the kingdom of Belgium, and seat of government and the chambers, on the small river Senne, has 106,000 inhabitants. It is divided into the upper and lower towns, the former being the newest as well as the most fashionable and healthy quarter, and built on a height. It contains the King’s palace, the chambers, and the chief hotels. The lower town abounds in find old picturesque buildings, the residences in former times of the Brabant noblesse, now occupied by merchants and tradespeople: the Grande Place, with its splendid Hotel de Ville in this quarter, is beyond doubt unrivalled as an instance of Gothic splendor in civic edifices” (Murray Hand‐book [1836], 134)..
Hills can be seen from Rose Terrace.

event.label: Arrived and stayed for four days.

note.p: While in Brussels, Mary says they stopped at Hotel de Ville bar in the Place Royale, where she first encountered a valet de chamber. Whent to an English church service performed by Mr. Drury, a companion of Lord Byron. She had taken walks with John James and John Ruskin in busy streets.

terrain.desc: “Laeken, a country residence of the King of Belgium, about three miles from the Port de Lachen, on the road to Vilvorde and Antwerp” (Murray Hand‐book [1836], 140)..
Located within the city of Brussels.

event.label: Pass through. Taken by carriage for visit.

note.p: Mary writes it as Laken. Unable to enter due to king and queen being in residence.

terrain.desc: Length: 8.12 sq mi

“This small village, on the outskirts of the forest, about 10 miles from Brussels, was the head-quarters of the English army, on the days before and following the battle to which it has given its name” (Murray Hand‐book [1836],142). “Waterloo is now nearly joined to Mont St. Jean, a long straggleing village, once almost a mile from it and lying on the edge of the field of battle” (Murray Hand‐book [1836],143).

event.label: Arrived at 8:30 am to visit site of battle.

note.p: Visited to see Battle of Quatre Bras fallen soldiers monument at a church and battle site.

terrain.desc: Length: 34.58 sq mi
Genappe is “19 miles from Brussels” (Murray Hand‐book [1836], 149).

event.label: Pass though in route to Spa

terrain.desc: Length: 13.81 sq mi

event.label: Pass through in route to Spa.

terrain.desc: Length: 7.83 sq mi
“Capital of the province of Namur, and a strong fortress, with 19,500 inhabitants, built at the junction of the Sambre and Meuse” (Murray Hand‐book [1836],149)..
Where the Sambre river meets the Meuse, which is a fine pebbly bed, and country well cultivated. The foritfications were well seen after crossing the bridge on the Huy road.

event.label: Pass through in route to Spa

terrain.desc: Length: 18.43 sq mi
Huy “is romantically situated on the Meuse, which divides it into two parts, and is traversed by an ancient stone bridge” (Murray Hand‐book [1836], 151)..

event.label: Pass thought in route to Spa.

note.p: Stage 1 of the day to Spa.

terrain.desc: Length: 26.79 sq mi
“Liege lies at the junction of the Ourthe with the Meuse” (Murray Hand‐book [1836], 152)..

event.label: Pass through in route to Spa

note.p: Stage 2. Admired a cathedral, visited a very old church build by the Spaniards and the Bishops palace.

terrain.desc: Length: 15.39 sq mi

“Spa is very prettily situated in a sort of semi-basin, in the midst of mountains forming part of the Ardennes Chain; the heights overhanging it are covered with shrubberies and intersected by healthful and airy walks, with pleasing prospects at intervals. A large part of the town is built close under the rocks, which, so far from holding out any encouragement to this near approximation, have on several occasions given the inhabitants warning to keep at a more respectful distance, by overwhelming their dwellings with vast masses of stone detached from above” (Murray Hand‐book [1836], 156).

note.p: Stage 3. Drank mineral water, and entered a church to hear music and mass.

terrain.desc: Length: 12.77 sq mi
Located “on the Vesdre” (Murray Hand‐book [1836], 159).

note.p: Stage 1 of this leg of the journey.

terrain.desc: Length: 62.10 sq mi
Pretty and clean town.

note.p: Stayed at Hotel de Ville. Visit to a cathedral that has an octagonal roof with paintings and gallery for viewing. Houses pictures by Vandyke and Rubens, gobline tapestry, alter picture of Mary, which is a gift from Mary Queen of Scotts, and tomb of Charlemagne.

p.ref: “Hast ever heard of the peace of Aix‐la‐Chapelle, reader?” [“Aix‐la‐Chapelle,” prose]

terrain.desc: Length: 34.9 sq mi
A melancholy looking fortress, with four thousand inhabitants, in the midst of a plain, surrounded by marshes and stagnant ditches, which render it very unhealthy (Murray Hand‐book [1836], 202).

event.label: Pass through in route to Cologne.

terrain.desc: Length: 156.43 sq mi
Cologne is a fortified town of 65,000 inhabitants, on the left bank of the Rhine, connected by a bridge of boats with a fortress and suburb of Deutz (Murray Hand‐book [1836], 207).

note.p: Stage 2. Not sure if they stayed at Reinbergh Hotel or Hotel Couronne Imperiale where George IV Stayed. Margaret stayed in bed while everyone else went to mass.

p.ref: “The noon was past, the sun was low” [“Cologne,” poem]
“And this is the birthplace of Rubens!” [“Cologne,” prose]

terrain.desc: Church

event.label: Pass through, but stoped to attend mass.

note.p: Mary took note of procession of girls and women, then men and boys.

terrain.desc: Length: 54.46 sq mi
Bonn is located “on the left bank of the Rhine” (Murray Hand‐book [1836], 217).

note.p: Walked to church on hill and met Mr. Schlegal.

terrain.desc: Length: 12.34 sq mi
“Near it is a mineral spring, Called Draischer Brunnen.” “Godesberg is a little more than one mile distant from the Rhine” (Murray Hand‐book [1836], 217).
Ruins - not very pretty. Between Bonn and Andernach.
Length: 12.80 sq mi

“As we proceed and approach Remagen on the left bank [of the Rhine], we open out a beautiful verdant mountain, well clothed with forest-trees, named Appolonisberg, which, with its old Gothic Church and convent crowning its summit, affords, when viewed from the inn at Remagen, one of the most pleasing among the many delightful scenes with which this magnificent river gratifies the traveller” (Barrow A Family Tour [1831], 186).
Ruins.
Ruins
Located within Remagen.
Ruins

note.p: Built by Roland, a nephew of Charlemagne who was in love with a lady in a neighbouring convent on an island, just under his castle, which is not an inn.

terrain.desc: Ruins
Castle
Ruins on opposite side of river from road to Coblentz.
Length: 20.55 sq mi
“At Andernach, the mountains on both sides of the Rhine again approach the water's edge, and form majestic defile (Murray Hand‐book [1836], 224)

event.label: Arrived to sleep for the night.

note.p: Mary and John drew the old Roman tower before leaving for Coblentz.

terrain.desc: Length: 40.55 sq mi
“Coblentz is a strongly fortified town, on the left bank of the Rhine, and the right of the Mosel” (Murray Hand‐book [1836], 227)
Moselle falls into Rhine at Coblentz.

event.label: Arrived and stayed at hotel Cheval Blanc. Visited Ehrenbreitstein fortress.

terrain.desc: Length: 29.01 sq mi

“A very ancient walled town, with 3500 inhabitant, and dark narrow streets, no better than lanes. Like many other places upon the Rhine, it owed its origin to a castle built by Dursus, which formed the rudiments of the future town” (Murray Hand‐book [1836], 232)
Length: 8.85 sq mi
S. Goar is situated immediately below The Rhine and Rheinfels (Barrow A Family Tour [1831], 196).

note.p: Mary claims to hear the most wonderful echoes, including one of a man who blew a horn.

terrain.desc: Located along and next to Hunsrück mountians.
Length: 8.85 sq mi
“Beyond this water-tower [Mausethurm] to the right, at the confluence of the Nahe and the Rhine, is the small town of Bingen” (The Rhenish Album Journal [1836], 241).
Villages located on both sides of the river.

event.label: Arrived and stayed at Hotel Chenin.

terrain.desc: ruins
ruins
ruins
ruins
ruins
ruins
ruins
ruins
A dismanteled fortification
ruins
ruins
ruins
ruins
ruins
ruins
ruins
ruins
ruins
Length: 37.74 sq mi
Mainz “lies on the left bank of the Rhine, nearly opposite the junction of the Main” (Murray Hand‐book [1836], 246).
Located where the Rhine meets the Main river.

note.p: Visited and dined at a hotel filled with Roman emperor's party

terrain.desc: Length: 78.7 sq mi
“Weisbaden is distant only six or eight miles from Mayence, by the high road, five miles by foot paths across the fields” (Murray Hand‐book [1836], 398).
Lies accross the Rhine from Mainz.

event.label: Arrived by boats crossing a river.

terrain.desc: Length: 95.87 sq mi

“Frankfort is a free town, and the seat of the German Diet: It lies on the right bank of the Main, and is connected by a stone bridge with the smaller quarter or suburb of Sachsenhausen, on the left bank” (Murray Hand‐book [1836], 403).
West of Wiesbaden, with the Main running through its center.

note.p: Stay at Hotel de Russie, which was built by a gentleman of property. Margaret stayed in bed while everyone else attended a German protestant church.

terrain.desc: “The country, as far as Darmstadt, is flat and unintersesting” (Murray Hand‐book [1836], 425).

note.p: Stage 1 of the day to Heidelberg.

terrain.desc: “It is a dull, unteresting tow, which need not detain the traveller long. The appearance of torpidity is increased by the extent of the surface over which it spread. The streets are straight and very wide, the squares numerous, and many of the houses are built singly, with intervals between them. ” (Murray Hand‐book [1836], 425).
“This small town of 3700 inhabitant, like most others on the Bergstrasse, has an ancient and decayed appearance, but is prettily situated ” (Murray Hand‐book [1836], 429).

“Weinheim is considered the most beautiful spot on the Bergstrasse; it lies on the Weschnitz, and has 4900 inhabitants, whose wealth consists in the orchards and vineyards around” (Murray Hand‐book [1836], 429).
“Heidelberg is beautifully situated on the left bank of the Neckar, on a narrow ledge between the river and the castle rock” (Murray Hand‐book [1836], 430).
Mary says that it is a very fine town that lies so beautifully at the foot of a hill with the river Neckar flowing close to it. They admired a castle on June 5.

p.ref: “Smiling from those bright rays kiss” [“Heidelberg” poem, part 1]
“All has yielded to it from time immemorial” [“Heidelberg” prose, part 3]

terrain.desc: “The city is nearly surrounded by the Hardt forest, which is intersected by roads radiating from the palace, and corresponding with the streets of the town. Beyond this are seen the silvery windings of the Rhine, and behind it the Vosges Mountain in France; while to the S. the picturesque outline of the Black Forest mountains, and on the N. those of the Bergstrasse, complete the panorama.” (Murray Hand‐book [1836], 435).

note.p: Stage 3. They admired botanical gardens, and she takes note that their churches are too much like a theater.

terrain.desc: “There can be but one opinion as to the beauty of the situation of the town of Baden, embosomed among hills forming an offset or commencement of the Black Forest range, and seated on the banks of the Oes, a stream which though insignificant in size, once formed the boundary line between the Franks and Alemanni” (Murray Hand‐book [1836], 439).
“The Rhine is seen at intervals on the right; its banks are flat and uninteresting” (Murray Hand‐book [1836], 445).

“Kehl, on the right bank of the Rhine, though dignified by the name of the town, resembles more nearly a village” (Murray Hand‐book [1836], 445). “Kehl: a well cultivated plain intervenes between this and Offenburg, situated on the high road from Carlsruhe to Basle, and at the entrance of the valley of Kinzig” (Murray Hand‐book [1836], 448).
Strasbourg is “on the Ill, which is on its way to join the Rhine, at the distance of about a mile, intersects the town in all directions, in canals” (Murray Hand‐book [1836], 445).

note.p: Visit to Strasbourg Cathedral, and Church of St. Thomas where a monument of Marechal Comte de Saxe is housed.

terrain.desc: Offenburg is “situated at the entrance of the valley of the Kinzig, on the direct road from Strasburg to Schaffhausen, which here crosses the road from Frankfort to Basle” (Murray Hand‐book [1836], 436).

note.p: Stage 1 of this leg in route to Schaffhausen.

terrain.desc: “This little town is beautifully situated under a height crowned by an old donjon keep, and at the foot of the main chain of the Black Forets range of mountains” (Murray Hand‐book [1836], 449).
“A market-town of about 3600 inhabitants, surrounded by bleak hills” (Murray Hand‐book [1836], 449).
Swiss-like cottages. So hilly, that they needed six horses. Picturesque town. Could seen the snowy summits of the Alps. The Rhine winds around richly cultivated fields and vineyards.

event.label: Arrived at 11 to a town with locked gates.

note.p: Attended German Protestant churches on Sunday, June 9. Walked through town to a curious old citadel. Walked by clear bright green river.

terrain.desc: “The Lake of Constance, anciently called Brigantinus is about eighteen leagues in length, five in breadth, and chiefly supplied by the Rhine” (Starke, Travels in Europe [1833], 635).

note.p: Ugly town but fine view of lake.

event.label: Pass through in route to Pfeffers. Rest for breakfast.
Pass through. Return in route to Coire.

note.p: Breakfast until noon on June 11, then to Pfeffers.

event.label: Arrival to visit baths of Pfeffers.

note.p: Baths lie quite in a hole, and the house is the most miserable place ever seen.

terrain.desc: Wild and beautiful pass of the Alps.
“The Defile between Coire and Splugen” (Starke, Travels in Europe [1833], 567).
Grand pass with immense high rocks that rise almost perpendicularly on each side of the Rhine. Houses surrounded by richly cultivated land are found on the lower parts of the mountains.
The Village of Splugen is “situated in the Valley of the Rheinwald” (Starke, Travels in Europe [1833], 567).

note.p: A poor place. Wet with no view.

terrain.desc: “The distance from La Riva to Chiavenna is about twelve miles” (Starke, Travels in Europe [1833], 596).
A small Italian town by high hills with very narrow streets, near a fine 300 foot high waterfall.

event.label: Depart to see Fiume Latte, an Italian torrential river.

note.p: Visited Somariva to see paintings and statues. Impressed with terraces containing pomegranites, olives, lemons, and myrtle. Attended Italian mass on Sunday, June 16.

terrain.desc: Milan is “seated on a peculiarly fertile spot, between the rivers Adda and Ticino (anciently Addua and Ticinus), and intersected by three Navigable Canals, one of which extends to Pavia” (Starke, Travels in Europe [1833], 47-48).

event.label: Depart for Pavia after dining at 1.

note.p: Saw magnificient cathedral with white marble, amphitheatre built by Napoleon, which can hold 42,000 spectators, and arch by Bonapart. They had ripe apricots and raspberries for dinner. Went to opera at Canobiano. On June 19, they went to Milan cathedral, Emperor's palace, Ambrosian Library, and Corso. On June 20, they went to Marengo Gate, San Lorenzo Basilica, and La Scala

terrain.desc: “Pavia is about seven leagues distant from Milan, and accessible both by land and water” (Starke, Travels in Europe [1833], 50). “It is placed in a fertile plain; and boasts an University long famed for the talents of its professors” (Starke, Travels in Europe [1833], 51).

note.p: Visited a rice field and Certosa, a monastary.

event.label: Arrive. Stopped because of heavy storm.
Pass through. Return in route to Alexandria.

note.p: Stopped on June 21 due to a heavy storm.

terrain.desc: Grand. Lies in a bay. Streets are narrow and dirty.

note.p: Mary, Margaret and John James went to mass on June 23, St. John the Baptist's eve, without John Ruskin. There were bonfires and fireworks. On June 24, they attended military mass, visited several palaces and universities, Lord Byron's house, a cathedral that holds the remains of St. John the Baptist, and the Opera of Anna Boleyna. On June 25, they bought collars with rich work and ortolans for dinner.

p.ref: “Of various trees a vista green” [poem, “Genoa,” part 1]
“Genoa” [poem, part 2, “Now rouse the ho. for Genoa straight”]

terrain.desc: Alessandria is “ a handome Fortress, seated in the midst of an extensive plain, and watered by the Tanaro” (Starke, Travels in Europe [1833], 117).

event.label: Pass through in route to Turin.

terrain.desc: “The modern walls or ramparts of this city, now the capital of Piedmont, are about four mile round, and contain near eighty-thousand persons: the Citadel, a particularly fine fortress, which the French almost destroyed, is now rebuilt ” (Starke, Travels in Europe [1833], 116).

note.p: Makes note of elegant rooms in palace. Anne and Salvador accompany children on walk to see insects and lizards on Thursday, June 27. There was a violent storm on June 28. St. Peter's day was Saturday, June 29. They went to the Royal chapel to seen the king and queen. They took a ride in the country, then visited the Argens Theatre.Sunday, June 30 they walked to Villa regina, which was more Italian than anything they had seen.

terrain.desc: Streams running through. Well drained country.
A town on Lake Maggiore

event.label: Depart for quick trip to visit Angera and Varese
Arrive. Return pass before boating trip.

note.p: They liked Arona better than Como, although inferior. Visited 112 feet bronze statue of S. Carlo Borromeo.
Mary describes it as a busy town where silk is made.
Visit to palace of Borromean family.

event.label: Pass through in route to Bavenna.

note.p: Largest of the three Borromean Islands.
Says it is at the end of the lake.
Duomo d'Ossala, as written by Mary, is a town in Ossola. She says that tt has splended views trhough passes equal to the Splugen.
Passed houses belonging to monks, and passed through galleries blown out of the rock. Brigg could be seen from far away.

terrain.desc: “Sion, anciently Sedunum, and in German Sitten, the Capital of the Haut-Valais, and built partly on the right bank of the Rhone, and partly on the River Sitten, is a very old Swiss Bishophric” (Starke, Travels in Europe [1833], 41). “Near Sion flows the river Morges, which divides the Haut from the Bas Valais ” (Starke, Travels in Europe [1833], 41).
Marshy and not so pretty looking.

event.label: Arrive. According to John James, they stayed in Sion on July 5.

note.p: Mary describes the town as dirty and desolate, with miserable creatures.

terrain.desc: Martigny (the ancient Octodurus), seated at the entrance of the Great Valley of the Rhone, where the roads from France, Italy, and Chamouni meet, was a well-built and flourishing Town, till nearly destroyed by a sudden and dreadful inundation of the Dranse; which occurred not long ago” (Starke, Travels in Europe [1833], 635).

event.label: Arrive to sleep. Return from Liddes.

note.p: Unsure where they came from the night before July 8.

terrain.desc: Small town at the foot of Mont St. Bernard.

event.label: Depart by foot to visit St. Pierre
Arrive. Return from walk to St. Pierre. Stay at St. Bernard hospice.

note.p: Stayed at the convent of St. Bernard, also know as St. Bernard Hospice. Mary notes that they woke to the sound of monks performing organ music at mass.

terrain.desc: Small town at the foot of Mont St. Bernard.

event.label: Pass through for visit on foot.

note.p: Bourg-Saint-Pierre is the village of St. Pierre

terrain.desc: Mary says that it is a vault or prison.
Located on a hill above Lake Geneva.

note.p: Mary says that someone bought Scott's Life of Swift and Rokeby. John James read the Swift life aloud in the evening. They visited Gibbon's and Kemble's houses on Sunday, July 14 after service.

event.label: Pass through in route to Fribourg.

terrain.desc: Strangest built town possible. One street is on the top of the houses of the street below. All streets are so steep that it is almost impossible for carriages to ascend.

event.label: Pass though in route to Fribourg

note.p: Purchased needle work from a nun on June 16.
Went to Monastary of Capuchins and college of Jesuits.
Clean town. Women wear black velvet capes close to their heads. Stayed at Hotel de Couronne. Appreciate comfortable, but not well furnished rooms. Went to French protestant church on Sunday, July 21.

event.label: Pass through. Return from Interlaken in route back to Berne.
Pass through in route to Sursees.
Pass through in route to Sursees.

note.p: Visit to Lake of Sempach on July 23.
Visited garden of French officer who allows people to view Lake of Lucerne form his situation. Saw the Lion Monument.

event.label: Pass through in route to Arth.

terrain.desc: Length: 16.25 sq mi
Located on the shore of Lake Zug between Righi and Rossberg

note.p: Where other tourists gathered in hope of ascending Mount Righi. On July 25, they ascended Righi on horses. Celebrated Brother William's birthday on July 26.
Where tourist gather to ascend Mount Righi

terrain.desc: Length: 16.25 sq mi
Located on the shore of Lake Zug between Righi and Rossberg.
Length:
Mountain summit in Alps.

note.p: Visit to Giesbach Falls. Had dinner before returing to Arth.

terrain.desc: Length:
Mountian summit in the alps. Near peak.
Length: 20.56 sq mi
Located along Lake Lauerz, and contains mountains Kleiner Mythen and Grosser Mythen.
Length: 38.24 sq mi
Located inside Schwyz.

note.p: A place of pilgrimage, to which the poor walk hundreds of miles in order to pay their devotions and to get things touched by the Virgin's shrine which acts as charms..

terrain.desc: Length: 0.67 sq mi
Along Lake Zurich.

note.p: Attended mass on Sunday, July 28. On July 29, someone copied a picture of D's bridge on the route de Saint Gothard. John is ill.

terrain.desc: Length: 33.93 sq mi
Where the Limmat river flows into Lake Zurich.

note.p: You can see river flowing beneath you at hotel built out over a bridge. John is still ill, and they search for English books to amuse him. Walked to where Limmat and Sil unite on August 1. Mills on river.On August 2, visit to museam and library.

terrain.desc: Length: 5.09 sq mi

“Baden, two Post from Vienna, is situated near a branch of the Kahlenberg: its Hot Baths were known to the ancient Romans, who called the Aquae Cetiae, or the Baths of Mons Cetius, now the Kahlenberg. Baden is a small Town, with extensive Suburbs; its Valley of S. Helena is lovely; and, considering its vicinity to the Styrian Alps, the climate is not rigorous” (Starke, Travels in Europe [1833], 511).

note.p: John James to bath. John Ruskin goes out first time since illness.

terrain.desc: Length: 2.22 sq mi
The Rhine flows through. (Find guidebook)
Along a the Rhein.

note.p: Crossed river on kind of bridge boat, which pulled to opposite by chain on a whee.
Crossed Rhine in Rheinfel in order to enter Basel.

terrain.desc: Lenth: 9.23 sq mi
Located along the Rhine.

event.label: Arrive by entering from German side as Swiss gates were closed.

note.p: Entered during battle at Leickstall between peasants and townspeople. The town was shut because Basel men were killed by peasants.

terrain.desc: Lenth: 2.42 sq mi
Located along the Rhine.

note.p: Located along the Aar river within the Jura mountains.

terrain.desc: Lenth: 8.20 sq mi
Lies at the foot of the Jura Mountains.
Length: 7.0 sq mi
Located on Lake Neuchatel within the Jura Mountains.

note.p: Town belongs to Prussia. Views of citadel.

terrain.desc: Length: 4.36 sq mi
South of Neuchatel. Surrounded with very low marshy and lately drained lands - stunted willows - large flat fields surrounded with poplars and long avenues for promenades.
Length: 1.55 sq mi
Farming area.
Length: 1.49 sq mi
Adjacent to Lake Geneva. A town with "fine trees giving to many parts the appearance of a grand park."

“Behind this little town of 2800 inhabitants rises the old castle of Wufflens, distinguished by its tall square donjon and group of minor turrets, built of brick, with deep machicola-tions.” “The distant view of Lausanne, seated on slopping hills and surmounted by its cathedral and castle, is pleas-ing. Between it and the lake, at the distance of 3/4 of a mile, stands the suburb or village of Ouchy (Inn: Ancre, at the water-side), which may be termed the port of Lausanne.” (Murray Hand‐book [1836], 429).
On lake of Geneva.

note.p: Stay during festival, even though dificult to find lodgings.

terrain.desc: Length: 6.15 sq mi

“Geneva, said to contain near thirty thousand inhabitants, and anciently a strong town belonging to the Allobroges, is delightfully situated on the immense Lake which bears its name; and divided into unequal parts by the Rhone” (Starke, Travels in Europe [1833], 35).
Cloth in Vegetation. Rhone River flows through town, split into two with houses built on island between.

note.p: Lots of English people in Geneva. Suspension bridge to hotel offers good view of Mont Blanc. English service on August 11, then evening walk with view of Mont Blanc. Visit Mr. Botte's showroom to buy jewelry. John sketched waterfall of Nant d'Arpenaz during return. They visited Marquis of Hertford's family with Lady Loveill on August 20, then the library, opera, and Voltaire's residence.

terrain.desc: Length: 10.48 sq mi
Half way between Geneva and Chamouni.

event.label: Pass through in route to Chamouni

note.p: Stopped for dinner during heavy storm.

terrain.desc: Length: 25.43 sq mi
Located in the Arve valley.

event.label: Arrive to stay for the night.
Pass through in route back to Geneva.

terrain.desc: Length: 94.77 sq mi
Richly cultivated land with beautiful road winding in a valley by side of Arve.

“The verdant clothing of the singular Valley of Chamouni is beatifully contrasted with cloud-capped mountains silvered byeternal snow; gloomy forrests, chiefly composed of firs; cottages and hamlets scattered here and there; brawling torrents; and rocks of porphyry and granite, interspersed with glaciers of a dazzling whiteness; whence rise sea-green pyramids of ice, which, when illuminated either by the sun or moon, exhibit a prospect unique and wonderful: but, nevertheless, so much has been siad in praise of this Valley, that Travellers are sometimes disappointed on seeing it.” (Starke, Travels in Europe [1833], 34).

note.p: Rain continues. Visit Mer de Glace.

p.ref: “I woke to here the lullaby” [“The Arve at Chamouni”]
“Journal of a Tour through France to Chamouni, 1835”
“Not such the night whose stormy might” [“Evening at Chamouni”]

terrain.desc: Length: 4.3 mi
Located in Chamouni valley in the Mont Blanc massif.

event.label: Pass through on mules for tour.

note.p: Also known as Mer de Glace. Lies in Chamouni. Witnessed small avalanche.

terrain.desc: Length: 4.94 sq mi
Length: 18.48 sq mi

“This City situated near the site of the ancient Lugdunum, founded by Lucius Munatius Plancus, forty-two years before the Christian era, on a Hill rising above the Modern Town, which contains about 100,470 inhabitants, and is, in point of wealth, the second City in France. It stands on a narrow piece of ground, between the Rhone (anciently called Rhodanus), and the Saone; is encircled by a rich and beautiful country, and owes one of its bridges, with several other embellishments, to Napoleon” (Starke, Travels in Europe [1833], 544).

note.p: Visit museum on August 24 to see Le Brun resurrection, last supper by Philippe de Champagne, drawings by Poussin, and Sneyders wild boar hunt. Attended French protestant church on August 25.

terrain.desc: Length: 10.44 sq mi

“This City, called Matisco, by the AEdui, to whom it originally belonged, contains 11,000 inhabitants, and a beautiful Quay, from which the Alps are discoverable” (Starke, Travels in Europe [1833], 544).
Length: 5.88 sq mi
Length: 15.60 sq mi

“This City, anciently Dibio, or Divio, the Capital of Burgundy, and supposed to contain about twenty-two thousand inhabitants, is well situated between the rivers Ouch and Suzon” (Starke, Travels in Europe [1833], 33).

“Auxerre is "seated on the left bank of the Yonne, and contains twelve thousand inhabitants: it stands, like all the large towns in this part of France, amidst wide-stretching vineyards” (Starke, Travels in Europe [1833], 32).

“Sens, once the Capital of the Galli-Sennones, and called by Caesar Agendicum, contains near eleven thousand inhabitants; is seated at the confluence of the Yonne and Vanne, and encircled by handsome Promenades and Walls, the lower part of which are exceedingly ancient and well worth notice” (Starke, Travels in Europe [1833], 31).

About the centre of this singular and extensive Forest [Forest of Fontainebleau] stands the Town of Fountaineblue: where the Hotel de la Ville de Londres is a good Inn” (Starke, Travels in Europe [1833], 31).

“Paris, once called Parisii vel Lutetia, is watered by the Seine, anciently Sequana; and previous to the dethronement of Louis XVI, was supposed to contain from seven to eight hundred thousand inhabitants; after that period the number was considerably diminished; but now it amounts to nearly nine hundred thousand, exclusive of Foreigners and Troops” (Starke, Travels in Europe [1833], 7).
“Amiens
“Amiens is watered by the Somme, and contains 40,000 inhabitants, together with a good inn, L'Hotel de la Poste” (Starke, Travels in Europe [1833], 533).
Length: 3.44 sq mi

“Boulogne, supposed to occupy the site of the ancient Gessoriacum, is a large Town, pleasantly situated at the mouth of the river Liane” (Starke, Travels in Europe [1833], 5). “Vestiges of a Tower, built in the days of Caligula, may be seen at Boulogne, which is reputed to contain thirty thousand inhabitants, beside British visitors; who, during peace, are very numerous” (Starke, Travels in Europe [1833], 6).
